Award.AwardTitle: SFS: Capacity Building: Collaborative Project: Cyber-Security Education for Community College Faculty in Texas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: To increase the number of faculty teaching cybersecurity content, the Department of Computer Science and the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Texas Tech University in partnership with the Center of Security Studies and Criminal Justice at Angelo State University are offering a professional development program in cybersecurity to community college faculty scholars across West Texas. Thirty faculty scholars from community and private colleges across West Texas are participating in a cyber-security education workshop and are mentored in the establishment of cybersecurity associate degrees and certification programs in their home institutions. The project provides a holistic approach to cybersecurity education by integrating the science and engineering aspects of cybersecurity issues with the management, ethical, and practical aspects as they relate to national defense and homeland security. It also introduces recent advances in cybersecurity research to improve cyber security education and explores various technical research and educational challenges. The project is increasing the number of educators knowledgeable in cybersecurity, resulting in a multiplying effect to students including minority groups that contribute to the workforce in the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Community colleges and their graduates are important contributors to the economic growth and workforce of the United States.  Continuous training and development, specifically tailored for instructors teaching at community colleges, play crucial roles to fulfill the critical mission of these institutes of higher learning. This project introduces a faculty development model and outreach program specifically designed for community colleges that aim at building a capacity of educators who are exposed to the recent advancements of science and technology. Through the introduced faculty development model, educators from community colleges are outreached, trained, and mentored with the target objectives of i) promoting cybersecurity education in these colleges by introducing new course modules, ii) enabling consistency of baccalaureate and associate degrees, and iii) enhancing the quality education across these types of organizations.

The project targeted and recruited faculty members from community colleges in Texas and offered two summer workshops where each of these was one-week long. The technical contents were delivered by professionals from Texas Tech University, Angelo State University, and the University of California at Riverside. The project identified over sixty colleges across Texas and directly contacted individual instructors and departments using various media. The project selected over thirty of these teachers to participate in the final programs of the two workshops that were held on the main campus of Texas Tech University. The final schedule for each workshop contained an exciting diverse program including sessions such as trainings, keynote speakers, panel discussions, hands-on experiences, and participants’ presentations. Once the training workshops ended, a mentorship protocol was developed and established to further assist the participants in creating their own cybersecurity course modules for use in their own institutes.

The program had four conclusions based on the three-stage evaluation of the project outcomes performed at the pre-workshop, post workshop, and follow-up mentoring stages by an independent evaluator. These were i) the program successfully recruited and hosted 32 participants (the proposed number of participants was thirty) from diverse backgrounds, ii) the participants’ knowledge and confidence increased significantly due to participation in the workshop, iii) the participants reported high levels of interest and actions to involve themselves in cybersecurity related activities and course offering in their own institution after the workshop, and iv) mentoring and support activities after the workshop were considered valuable in promoting participants’ engagement in various cybersecurity activities. 

In Year 1 of the project, 44% of the participants were female. Similarly, 44% of the participants were Hispanic and African American faculty. In Year 2 of the project, 40% of the participants were female and a substantial number of the participants were from diverse background ethnicities including African American, Asian, Hispanic/Latino, and Native Americans. The project met each milestone within the proposed plan and delivered upon its promises and exceeded the expectations. The outcomes of the workshop evaluation are summarized below.

I) Participants’ Knowledge. Post knowledge ratings were significantly higher after each of the workshops. An increase of 23% and 13% were observed in the participants’ knowledge after the workshop in Year 1 and Year 2, respectively.  Effect sizes calculated were high ranging from 0.69 to 1.53 in the cybersecurity topics presented during the workshops.
